headline: Applying to university  hidden costs
text: From printing charges to bills for books and special equipment, student life comes with all sorts of extra and often unplanned-for costs. Many universities publish guidance for new students so you can factor these expenses into your budget but it's also a good idea to ask a current undergraduate which purchases are essential, and which you can do without. Receiving your first university reading list is an exciting experience, so it's tempting to buy every item mentioned, says Catherine Pearce, a third-year medic at Cardiff University. "When I was accepted to study medicine I was so ecstatic that I went out and bought a model skull. I now live in a house full of medics  and rather unnecessarily we have one skull per person. I also own quite a lot of shiny, unopened textbooks." Faculty libraries are well stocked, so there's no need to buy every recommended book  and once you're registered as a student you can visit university libraries across the country through the Access scheme. Search for texts online Google books and Project Gutenberg have excellent archives  and use your university's facilities as much as possible. "Once you settle in you soon pick up ways to save money," says Agnes Bataclan, a second-year photography student at the London College of Fashion. "I book in advance to use university equipment and I avoid printing costs by handing work in digitally wheneverpossible." If you're concerned about costs you can alsoapply for a scholarship. Checkout the guidance online provided by Student Finance England for information about government, university and charity grants.     Guardian students sign up banner
